conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine when particles A and B are the farthest apart.

The image shows a velocity-time graph with two particles, A and B. Particle A starts from rest, accelerates linearly to a maximum velocity, and then decelerates back to rest. Particle B accelerates uniformly from rest to a maximum velocity and then decelerates uniformly back to rest.
Particle A accelerates from 0 to 2v₀ from t = 0 to t = 2t₀.
Particle B accelerates from 0 to 2v₀ from t = 0 to t = 4t₀.
Particle A decelerates from 2v₀ to 0 from t = 2t₀ to t = 3t₀.
Particle B decelerates from 2v₀ to 0 from t = 4t₀ to t = 6t₀.
The maximum distance between A and B occurs when A is at its maximum velocity and B is at its maximum acceleration.
This happens at t = 2t₀ for A and t = 4t₀ for B.
The distance between A and B is the difference in their positions, which is the difference in their velocities multiplied by time.
The time when A and B are the farthest apart is when the distance is maximum.
This occurs at t = 5t₀, where A is decelerating and B is accelerating.
